sub.page.body.para: If n is one of the integers 1,2,3, then we may visualize \RNr[n] as follows

Visualizing \RNr=\RNr[1]: The set of all
1-tuples
i.e. a single number x between brackets: (x)
forms a line on which one point has been designated to be 0, and a unit of measurement has been chosen. – It is customary to call the line the x-axis.

Visualizing \RNr[2]: The set of all
2-tuples or ordered pairs
i.e. two number x and y between brackets: (x,y). Such 2-tuples are also called ordered pairs.
ordered pair
another word for 2-tuple; i.e. an expression of the form (x,y), where x and y are numbers.
forms a plane on which one point \mathbf{0} has been designated to be the origin, and two perpendicular lines with a unit of measurement have been chosen. – It is customary to draw one of these axes horizontal and call it the x-axis. The other line will then appear vertical and will be called the y-axis.

If we want to give the name P to the point (2,1)
displayed above
Animation of relating ordered pairs to points in the plane
, we write P(2,1) to express that it has coordinates 2 and 1.

Visualizing \RNr[3]: The set of all
3-tuples or ordered triples
i.e. three numbers x,y,z between brackets: (x,y,z)
can be related to points in the world surrounding us. We pick one point, \mathbf{0}, to act as the origin. Then we pick three perpendicular lines with a unit of measurement.. – In the picture below,

li.para: the first coordinate axis points toward you. We call it the x-axis.
the second coordinate axis goes from left to right. We call the y-axis.
the third coordinate axis has a vertical direction. We call it the z-axis

sub.page.body.para: If we want to give the name Q to the point (3,2,2) displayed above, we write Q(3,2,2). To plot it, consider the box in the picture above. Then, starting from the origin,

li.para: move 3 units in the x-direction (to arrive a the bottom front left corner of the box),
from there move 2 units parallel to the y-direction (to arrive at the front right bottom corner of the box),
from there move 2 units parallel to the z-direction (to arrive at the blue corner of the box)

sub.page.body.para:
You can also see an
animation
Animation of plotting ordered triples in a 3D-coordinate system.
of this plotting process for several points in \RNr[3].

li.para: points on the first coordinate axis are given by triples of the form (x,0,0), where x is an arbitrary number.
points on the second coordinate axis are given by triples of the form (0,y,0), where y is an arbitrary number.
points on the third coordinate axis are given by triples of the form (0,0,z), where z is an arbitrary number.
